item.title: Working with R and Python
item.description: Looking at Earthquake Data using R and Python Fun Fact: I visited Fiji when I was 4 and have been dying to go back ever since! I have extended family who lives there and an aunt who grew up there when she was young after moving from India. All of the pictures I have from this trip are on old film or physically printed so here's a picture of this beautiful place that I found online.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: Modeling 0. Introduction (5 pts) library(dplyr) library(tidyverse) library(ggplot2) library(sandwich) library(lmtest) library(glmnet) library(vegan) Heart <- read.csv("heart.csv") Heart <- Heart %>% mutate(thalrevised = case_when(thal==1 ~ "normal", thal==2 ~ "fixed defect", thal==3 ~ "reversable defect")) #create categorical variable from original thal variable Heart <- Heart %>% na.omit() #remove any potential NA values Heart <- Heart[-c(2:3, 6:7, 9, 11:13)] #remove unneeded variables This dataset contains data collected to look at the presence of heart disease in the observed patients across the following four databases: Cleveland, Hungary, Switzerland, and Long Beach V.

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis on World Happiness Report Data
item.description: 0. Introduction (4 pts) My chosen dataset yields from the World Happiness Report of 2015 as found on Kaggle. The World Happiness Report is used by experts in a variety of fields to look at how well being can be evaluated as a measure to analyze the progress of countries. The original variables included in this specific dataset are: Country, Region, Happiness Rank, Happiness Score, Standard Error, Economy (GDP per Capita), Family, Health (Life Expectancy), Trust (Government Corruption), Generosity, and Dystopia Residual.
